TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Clayey-skeletal, mixed, superactive, frigid Typic Haplustalfs

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Trampas cobbly sandy loam, forested.  (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise noted.)
01 & 02--1 inch to 0; needles, leaves, twigs, etc., in various stages of decomposition.
A1--0 to 2 inches; grayish brown (10YR 5/2) cobbly sandy loam, very dark grayish brown (10YR 3/2) moist; weak very fine and fine granular structure; soft, friable; many very fine and fine roots; many very fine interstitial pores; 25 percent cobbles, 30 percent gravel; neutral (pH 6.6); abrupt smooth boundary.  (2 to 4 inches thick)
A2--2 to 7 inches; light gray (10YR 7/2) gravelly sandy loam, yellowish brown (10YR 5/4) moist; weak very fine and fine roots; many very fine interstitial pores; 30 percent gravel; slightly acid (pH 6.4); clear smooth boundary.  (5 to 10 inches thick)
B1t--7 to 10 inches; brown (10YR 5/3) extremely cobbly sandy clay loam, dark brown (10YR 4/3) moist; moderate fine subangular blocky structure; hard, firm, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; few fine, medium, and coarse roots; many very fine interstitial pores; many thin clay films on peds and common thin clay films on rock fragments; 30 percent cobbles, 40 percent gravel; slightly acid (pH 6.4); clear smooth boundary.  (4 to 6 inches thick)
B21t--11 to 35 inches; reddish brown (5YR 5/3) extremely gravelly clay, reddish brown (5YR 4/3) moist; moderate fine and medium subangular blocky structure; very hard, very firm, sticky and plastic; few very fine, fine and medium roots; many very fine tubular pores; common thick clay films on peds and on rock fragments; 60 percent gravel and 20 percent cobbles; slightly acid (pH 6.2); gradual smooth boundary.  (9 to 14 inches thick)
B3t--35 to 49 inches; yellowish red (5YR 5/6) extremely cobbly sandy clay loam, reddish brown (5YR 4/4) moist; weak fine and medium subangular blocky structure; very hard, firm, sticky and plastic; few very fine roots; common very fine tubular pores; common thick clay films on peds and on rock fragments; 40 percent gravel and 40 percent cobbles; medium acid (pH 6.0); gradual smooth boundary.  (10 to 14 inches thick)
C--49 to 61 inches; reddish brown (5YR 5/4) extremely cobbly light sandy clay loam, reddish brown (5YR 4/4) moist; massive; very hard, firm, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; 55 percent cobbles, 40 percent gravel; medium acid (pH 6.0).

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Rio Arriba County, New Mexico; AMS Photo Number 2030, NW1/4 SE1/4 section 30, T.22N., R.11E.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  The mean annual soil temperature is 42 to 47 degrees F. and the mean summer soil temperature is 52 to 56 degrees F.  The solum ranges in thickness from 40 to 60 inches.
The A horizon has value of 5 through 7 dry, 3 through 5 moist, and chroma of 2 or 3.  It is sandy loam or loam and has 20 to 60 percent rock fragments.
The Bt horizon has hue of 5YR or 7.5YR, value of 4 or 5 dry or moist, and chroma of 3 through 6.  It is clay or sandy clay and has 50 to 80 percent rock fragments.
The C horizon has hue of 5YR or 7.5YR and value of 5 or 6.  It is sandy clay loam or sandy loam and has 75 to 95 percent rock fragments.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  These are the Bignell, Crest and Pinata series.  Bignell soils have sola more than 60 inches thick and have A&B horizons.  Crest soils have limestone at depths of less than 40 inches.  Pinata soils have rock fragments that are mainly of stone size.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  The Trampas soils are on dissected very old alluvial fans and alluvial plains at elevations of 7,500 to 9,000 feet.  Slopes range from 15 to 50 percent.  The soils formed in transported material from mixed sources.  The annual precipitation is 18 to 25 inches and about 60 percent of the precipitation occurs as snow and winter rain.  The annual temperature is about 45 degrees F. and the average summer temperature is about 56 degrees F.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Derecho, Diamante, Maes, and Mirand soils.  Derecho soils lack an A2 horizon and are neutral or mildly alkaline in all parts.  Diamante soils are Paleboralfs.  Maes soils are Glossoboralfs.  Mirand soils are in a fine family of Mollic Eutroboralfs.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Well drained; medium runoff; slow permeability.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  Used for timber production, seasonal grazing, watershed, recreation, and wildlife habitat.  Vegetation is mainly ponderosa pine with an understory of Oregon grape, buckwheat, yarrow, squirreltail, pine dropseed, and Arizona fescue.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Northern New Mexico.  The series is moderately extensive.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Bozeman, Montana

ORIGIN.content:
SERIES ESTABLISHED:  Taos Area, New Mexico, 1976.
National Cooperative Soil Survey
U. S. A.
